column1: '''''Bretagne''''' was a large 110-gun three-decker French [[ship of the line]], built at [[Brest, France
column2: Brest]], which became famous as the flagship of the Brest Fleet during the [[American War of Independence]]. She was funded by a ''[[don des vaisseaux]]'' grant by the [[Estates of Brittany]]. <ref name=Roche85 /> She was active in the European theatres of the [[Anglo-French War (1778–1783)
column3: Anglo-French War]] and of the [[French Revolutionary Wars]], notably taking an important role in the [[Glorious First of June]]. Later, she took part in the  [[Croisière du Grand Hiver]] and was broken up.<ref name=forrer21 />

column1: The [[Seven Years' War]] had left the [[French Navy]] severly depleted, and the Crown did not have funds to replace the ships lost during the conflict. In late 1761 [[Étienne François, duc de Choiseul]] took the direction and proposed that the great institutions of France make voluntary donations, a scheme named ''[[don des vaisseaux]]''. On 1 September 1762,<ref name=nomprestigieux>{{cite web
column4: title=La Bretagne : origine d’un nom prestigieux dans la Marine française
column9: date=1 February 2019}}</ref> the [[Estates of Brittany]] gathered at the Couvent des Cordeliers in Rennes<ref name=binet212>Binet, p.212</ref> and decided to raise one million [[Livre tournois
column10: Livres tournois]] in order to offer a 100-gun [[Three-decker]].<ref name=binet211>Binet, p.211</ref> [[Ship-of-the-line lieutenant
column11: Lieutenant]] Jean-Claude Louis de Quelen rode to [[Choisy-le-Roi]]<ref name=binet215>Binet, p.215</ref> to inform [[Louis XV of France
column12: Louis XV]], arriving on 5 and returning on 9 with acceptance letters from the King and from the Duke de Choiseul.<ref name=nomprestigieux /> Administrative dispositions for a load started on 2 November, and were completed by 17.<ref name=binet217>Binet, p.217</ref> Budget would eventually reach  1,010,000 [[Livre tournois

column1: The donation had political connotations, both in terms of rivalry between the various donating institutions, and for the status of Bretagne within France.<ref name=forrer13>Forrer, p. 13</ref> Therefore, the Estates of Brittany attached their gift to a number of requests: that the ship be named ''Bretagne'' rather than ''États de Bretagne'', that the crew be composed of Bretons exlusively, and that the ship be a three-decker.<ref name=binet213>Binet, p.213</ref> Furthermore, rather than donate funds that the Crown would invest in construction, the Estates demanded to supervise construction themselves at the shipyards of the [[French East India Company]] in [[Lorient]].<ref name=nomprestigieux /><ref name=binet211 />

On 2 November 1761, the Commission of the Estates of Brittany in charge of construction mandated [[Antoine Groignard]] as chief engineer, with Gaubry as deputy and Damel as an advisor.<ref name=binet218>Binet, p.218</ref> Groignard worked both for the French Royal Navy and for the French East India Company; he had recently directed the construction of the 80-gun [[French ship Orient (1756)
column5: ''Solitaire'']], and was supervising ongoing construction of the 74-gun [[French ship Diligent (1763)
column8: ''Bordelois'']] in Lorient, that of the 56-gun [[French ship Utile (1764)
column11: ''Flamand'']] in [[Bordeaux]], and four frigates in Nantes.<ref name=binet219>Binet, p.219</ref>

column1: On 17 November 1761, Groignard sent of proposal for a budget between 919,000 and 1,115,000 pounds.<ref name=binet220>Binet, p.220</ref> The shipyards in Lorient received their first orders in early December.<ref name=binet221>Binet, p.221</ref> Choiseul wrote the Groignard to congratulate him for his appointment, and to argue in favour of building a 80-gun two-decker, with [[36-pounder long gun
column2: 36-pounders]] on the lower battery and [[24-pounder long gun
column3: 24-pounders]] on the upper, although he conceded that political considerations mandated a three-decker. He also reminded of the shortcomings of [[French ship Royal Louis (1759)
column4: ''Royal Louis'']], an unsuccessful 100-gun of the time.<ref name=binet222>Binet, p.222</ref>

column1: Groignard hoped to complete construction by 1763, but delay in complete the 1-million load and difficulties in stocking construction wood soon set the schedule back. On 28 March 1763, Groignard sent completed plans to the construction commission, which failed to forward them to Choiseul. On 6 May, Choiseul wrote directly to Groignard to enquire, and setting further requirements that the artillery be set on the three batteries (limiting armament of the castles),<ref name=forrer14>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.14</ref> and that autonomy be sufficient to feed 1,000 men for six months, with water for two.<ref name=binet223>Binet, p.223</ref> By July, construction was expected to be completed in 1765,<ref name=binet225>Binet, p.225</ref> and there were several exchanges of letters and budget estimations between various administrations and rival naval engineers, second-guessing Groignard and arguing about the furniture and spare parts needed for the ship.<ref name=binet228>Binet, p.228</ref>

column4: Depiction on ''Bretagne'' flying the white ensign of the [[Ancien Régime]].]]

column1: By 3 January 1764, the Commission was requesting revised versions of the plans as to reduce the dimensions of ''Bretagne''.<ref name=binet231>Binet, p.231</ref> On 23, Groignard submitted his new plans, along with a memorandum underlining that this version would now allow the ship to hold six month worth of food and was compromising her stability, speed and manœuverability.<ref name=binet235>Binet, p.235</ref> On 19 February, Choiseul declined to approve the revised plans and requested a third version; Groignard completed quickly and went directly to Paris himself to submit them, short-circuiting the construction Commission of the Estates of Brittany<ref name=binet237>Binet, p.237</ref> and talking Choiseul out of the notion that the lower battery should be armed with 24-pounders instead of 36-pounders.<ref name=binet238>Binet, p.238</ref><ref name=forrer14 /> On 7 May, Choiseul informed the Commission that his plans had met with approval and that the construction could begin.<ref name=binet238 />

The Commission then started procuring the raw materials needed for the construction, notably wood, fabric for the sails, iron and cables. Lacking experience in the matter, it requested advice from Roth, director of the East India Company in Lorient,<ref name=forrer14 /> who replied on 1 April with a long memorandum.<ref name=binet239>Binet, p.239</ref> Besides explaining how to assess the quality of the materials, how to transport it on land and how to store it, the memorandum observed that a number of parts would need to be obtained from outside of Bretagne, and sometimes even abroard, notably from the Netherlands.<ref name=binet240>Binet, p.240</ref> Providers would span from [[Newcastle]] to [[Saint Petersburg]] and [[Riga]].<ref name=binet240 />

In August 1764, Groignard started laying down parts in Lorient shipyard, hoping to take advantage of the summer weather and of a moment of low activity by the East India Company. However, the fluyts needed to transport construction wood were damaged and a lack of wood and nails soon slowed down the work.<ref name=binet242>Binet, p.242</ref> In December, the Estates and the Company signed an understanding that Groignard would have access to the parts and materials stocked in the Company stores, and that the Estates would replenish them within three months.<ref name=binet243>Binet, p.243</ref> On 12 December, the keel was laid down, the bow had been assembled, and the [[Frame (nautical)
column2: frames]] were made and ready to be installed.<ref name=binet244>Binet, p.244</ref>

column1: However, on 12 January 1765, the Commission ordered that the construction be halted, <ref name=binet244 /> and summoned Groignard to Nantes.<ref name=binet249>Binet, p.249</ref> Realising its lack of competence, the Commission had decided cease procuring material directly and to mandate a harbour for the overall budget of the project, either Lorient or Brest.<ref name=binet250>Binet, p.252</ref> By March, Brest had won the contract; <ref name=binet254>Binet, p.254</ref> the ship was dismantled and her pieces were brought to Brest in May 1765.<ref name=demerliac_1774_15 /> Groignard remained in charge of the work, <ref name=binet254 /> while the Commission was little involved from then on.<ref name=binet255>Binet, p.255</ref>

On 5 July 1765, the keel was laid down in Brest<ref name=binet256>Binet, p.256</ref> in the upper dry dock of Pontaniou.<ref name=forrer15>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.15</ref> By mid-July, the framing was completed.<ref name=binet256 /> By mid-September, the hull was [[Caulk
column2: caulked]].<ref name=binet257>Binet, p.257</ref> In late February 1766, carpenters had completed the [[orlop deck]] and were preparing construction of the [[Gun deck
column3: first battery]].<ref name=binet257 /> In April, the sides were completed up to the lower battery, and the decks of the lower and middle batteries were installed.<ref name=binet258>Binet, p.258</ref> On 24 May 1766, ''Bretagne'' was launched.<ref name=binet258 /><ref name=Roche85 />

column1: Completion of the ship remained slow, <ref name=forrer15 /> and ''Bretagne'' was declared completed on 30 September 1767. <ref name=demerliac_1774_15 /><ref name=forrer15 /> ''Bretagne'' was commissioned in 1768,<ref name=binet261>Binet, p.261</ref> but in June 1770 work remained to be done to make her sea worthy, and she spent the whole year fitting out.<ref name=forrer15 /> On 30 November 1771, she was declared in need of an extensive refit.<ref name=forrer15 />

In 1773, ''Bretagne'' was listed as serving in the Brest Brigade of the Ponant Division of the Navy.<ref name=binet261 /> However, her state was deteriorating, and harbour director Count de Breugnon sent her to a dry dock, where she entered on 9 August.<ref name=forrer15 /> In 1775, [[Louis Guillouet, comte d'Orvilliers
column2: Orvilliers]], took command of the Brest squadron and, finding her timbers rotten, petitionned [[Antoine de Sartine
column3: Sartine]] for an extensive refit;<ref name=binet261 /><ref name=forrer15 />  reconstruction started on 1 September 1776, taking  480,000 pounds, and ''Bretagne'' was launched on 7 April 1777. She took two more months for fitting out.<ref name=forrer15 />
Later, naive representation of the [[Battle of Ushant (1778)
column4: Battle of Ushant]] depicting ''Bretagne'' fighting [[HMS Victory

column3: Representation of ''Bretagne'' circa 1782, [[Peabody Essex Museum]], [[Salem, Massachusetts]].]]

column1: She took part in most of the engagements of the European theatre of the [[Anglo-French War (1778–1783)
column2: Anglo-French War]],<ref name=binet262>Binet, p.262</ref> notably the [[Battle of Ushant (1778)
column3: Battle of Ushant]] in 1778, where she served as [[Louis Guillouet, comte d'Orvilliers
column4: Orvilliers]]' flagship. <ref name=Roche85 /> She took part in the [[Armada of 1779]], but an epidemic aboard forced her to return to Brest in September.<ref name=binet262 /> In 1779, her armament was reinforced by adding 10 further [[6-pounder long gun
column5: 6-pounders]] to her [[quarterdeck]], turning her into a 110-gun.<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> On 2 September 1780, ''Bretagne'' left Brest for Cadiz, where she took part in the [[Great Siege of Gibraltar]].

column1: Although she had good nautical qualities,''Bretagne'' had a tendency to leak and [[Hogging and sagging
column2: hog]], <ref name=forrer20>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.20</ref> and from February to April 1781, she underwent a refit in Brest and notably received a [[copper sheathing]].<ref name=demerliac_1774_15 /> ''Bretagne'' then undertook an expedition under Captain Soulange<ref name=forrer20 /> in [[Luc Urbain de Bouëxic, comte de Guichen
column3: Guichen]]'s squadron in the Mediterranean and the Atlantic from 22 June to early September.<ref name=forrer19>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.19</ref>

column1: After spending three months in Brest, she sailed again on 12 December 1781.<ref name=forrer19 /> She sustained damage in foul weather, <ref name=forrer19 /> notably in a hurricane on 25 and 26 December.<ref name=binet262 /> At her return to Brest, ''Bretagne'' was in need of serious repairs, and Guichen, to his chagrin, had to transfer his flag to [[French ship Terrible (1780)
column2: ''Terrible'']].<ref name=forrer19 /> In 1782, her keel had [[Hogging and sagging
column3: hogged]] by 1'7\" ''pied du roi''.<ref name=demerliac_1774_15 /> ''Bretagne'' was refitted in Brest from 2 March to July 1782,<ref name=demerliac_1792_19>Demerliac, ''1792—1799'', n°1, p. 19</ref> undergoing extensive repairs of her hull but losing her copper sheating in the process.<ref name=forrer20 />

column1: On 8 July 1782,<ref name=forrer20 /> ''Bretagne'' departed Brest under Captain [[Charles Picot de Dampierre]] to join the franco-Spanish combined fleet still [[Great Siege of Gibraltar
column2: besieging Gibraltar]], arriving on 11 along with [[French ship Invincible (1780)
column6: ''Guerrier'']].<ref>Troude, vol.2, p.128</ref> Her cutter rescued men from the crew of the Spanish floating battery ''Talla Piedra'' on 13 September. ''Bretagne'', under Dampierre,<ref>Kerguelen-Trémarec, p.323</ref><ref>Troude, vol.2, p.134</ref> blockaded Gibraltar until 10 October, when a gale damaged her rigging, killing a [[helmsman]] and ripping anchors from the ship. <ref name=forrer20 /> On 13 October 1782, the fleet moved to intercept a British squadron, resulting in the [[Battle of Cape Spartel]] on 20 where ''Bretagne'' sustained 5 men wounded.<ref name=binet262 /><ref name=forrer20 /> ''Bretagne'' then returned to Cadiz harbour in preparation for an expedition to America under [[Charles Henri Hector d'Estaing
column7: Admiral d'Estaing]], but by then the [[Peace of Paris (1783)
column8: Peace of Paris]] had been concluded and ''Bretagne'' returned to Brest.<ref name=forrer20 />

column1: ''Bretagne'' was refitted in Brest in 1788 until the end of the year.<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> The [[poop deck]] was removed to improve stability. <ref name=forrer20 />
''Bretagne'' was refitted in Brest from 1792 to June 1793,<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> 6 [[Obusier de vaisseau
column2: obusiers de vaisseau]] being added that year.<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> ''Bretagne'', under Captain [[Joseph de Richery]], became the flagship of Admiral [[Jean-Amable Lelarge]].<ref>Troude, vol.2, p.287</ref><ref name=forrer21>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.21</ref> In September 1793, her crew was involved in the [[Quibéron mutinies]]; <ref name=Roche85 /> in reaction [[Jeanbon Saint-André]] had Lelarge destitued and Richery arrested,<ref>Troude, vol.2, p.290</ref> and ''Bretagne'' renamed to '''''Révolutionnaire'''''.<ref name=forrer21 />

column1: Captain [[Daniel Vandongen]]<ref>Johnson, p. 96</ref> took command of ''Révolutionnaire'' and put her in good order. By 19 June 1794, she was copperd and fully armed.<ref name=forrer21 />

On 16 May 1794, the fleet departed Brest.<ref name=forrer21 /><ref>Troude, vol.2, p.328</ref>  On 28, the British and French squadrons met, leading to the skirmishes that would culminate into the so-called [[Glorious First of June]].<ref name=Roche85 /> The French line of battle was set in reverse order, and ''Révolutionnaire'' found herself at the rear, last ship in the line.<ref name=forrer21 /> In action against five or six 74-gun ships ([[HMS Russell (1764)
column5: ''Leviathan'']])<ref name=Roche85 /> she was badly damaged, losing all her masts. At 0930,  a shot killed Captain Vandongen,<ref name=forrer21 /> leaving ''Révolutionnaire'' without experienced command as the first lieutenant was wounded and the second lieutenant has already been killed.<ref name=johnson87>Johnson, p.87</ref> Third Lieutenant Renaudeau assumed command but was incapacitated almost immediately as well, and Fourth Lieutenant Dorré took over.<ref name=troude334>Troude, vol.2, p.334</ref> ''Révolutionnaire'' was isolated and defenceless, and avoided captured mostly thanks to [[Richard Howe, 1st Earl Howe
column6: Admiral Howe]]'s order to his ships to regroup.<ref name=forrer21 />{{refn
column7: A rumour states that ''Révolutionnaire'' struck her colours at some point, which her officers disputed.<ref name=forrer21 />
column8: group=Note}} In the night, ''Révolutionnaire'' lost her [[mizen]] and her [[mainmast]]. <ref name=troude334 /> The next day, she met [[French ship Audacieux (1784)
column10: ''Unité'']], of Nielly's squadron; ''Audacieux'' took ''Révolutionnaire'' in tow and brought her to [[Île-d'Aix]], where she arrived on 8 June<ref name=troude334 /> with 160 crewmembers killed or wounded.<ref name=johnson87 />

column1: ''Révolutionnaire'' was fully repaired and rigged anew at Île-d'Aix, which entailed the construction of a workshop specially for that purpose, as well as bringing all parts from [[Rochefort, Charente-Maritime
column2: Rochefort]]. She was ready again on 7 August 1794, and rejoined Brest on 27 of the same month.<ref name=forrer21 />

column1: On 29 December 1794, under Captain Le Gouardun,<ref name=forrer21 /> ''Révolutionnaire'' departed Brest for the [[Croisière du Grand Hiver]], where she was very heavily damaged. <ref name=Roche85 /> She limped back to Brest on 2 February 1795, her hull leaking heavily.<ref name=forrer21 />

Too damaged in the [[Croisière du Grand Hiver]] to be repaired,<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> she was struck on 28 January 1796<ref name=demerliac_1774_15 /><ref name=forrer21 /> and broken up between January and May 1796. <ref name=Roche85 />
A scale model of the ''Bretagne'' is on display at Brest naval museum ([[:commons:Category:Model of Bretagne-MnM 13 MG 4
column2: MnM 13 MG 4]]). Admiral [[François-Edmond Pâris]] states that it was built by of under supervision from [[Pierre-Alexandre-Laurent Forfait
column3: Forfait]] around 1780.<ref name=forrer17 /> The model  depicts ''Bretagne'' in her 1777 state (no coppering yet, but already 16 guns on the castles, 10 on the quarterdeck and 6 on the forecastle).<ref name=forrer17>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.17</ref> The ornaments are not quite realistic: the aft is overly decorated compared to the drawings to master sculptor Lubet, and the [[figurehead]] is a woman carrying the arms of Bretagne, reflecting a project that was never realised in reality. The actual figurehead featured a lion carrying the arms of Bretagne.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Maquette de bateau, Bretagne, vaisseau de 100 canons, 1766

column1: ''Bretagne'' is depicted on the painting ''Vue du port de Brest en 1793'' by [[Jean-François Hue]].<ref name=forrer18>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p. 18</ref>

On 6 May, Choiseul wrote directly to Groignard to enquire, and setting further requirements that the artillery be set on the three batteries (limiting armament of the castles),<ref name=forrer14>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.14</ref> and that autonomy be sufficient to feed 1,000 men for six months, with water for two.<ref name=binet223>Binet, p.223</ref> By July, construction was expected to be completed in 1765,<ref name=binet225>Binet, p.225</ref> and there were several exchanges of letters and budget estimations between various administrations and rival naval engineers, second-guessing Groignard and arguing about the furniture and spare parts needed for the ship.<ref name=binet228>Binet, p.228</ref>

column1: By 3 January 1764, the Commission was requesting revised versions of the plans as to reduce the dimensions of ''Bretagne''.<ref name=binet231>Binet, p.231</ref> On 23, Groignard submitted his new plans, along with a memorandum underlining that this version would now allow the ship to hold six month worth of food and was compromising her stability, speed and manœuverability.<ref name=binet235>Binet, p.235</ref> On 19 February, Choiseul declined to approve the revised plans and requested a third version; Groignard completed quickly and went directly to Paris himself to submit them, short-circuiting the construction Commission of the Estates of Brittany<ref name=binet237>Binet, p.237</ref> and talking Choiseul out of the notion that the lower battery should be armed with 24-pounders instead of 36-pounders.<ref name=binet238>Binet, p.238</ref><ref name=forrer14 /> On 7 May, Choiseul informed the Commission that his plans had met with approval and that the construction could begin.<ref name=binet238 />

The Commission then started procuring the raw materials needed for the construction, notably wood, fabric for the sails, iron and cables. Lacking experience in the matter, it requested advice from Roth, director of the East India Company in Lorient,<ref name=forrer14 /> who replied on 1 April with a long memorandum.<ref name=binet239>Binet, p.239</ref> Besides explaining how to assess the quality of the materials, how to transport it on land and how to store it, the memorandum observed that a number of parts would need to be obtained from outside of Bretagne, and sometimes even abroard, notably from the Netherlands.<ref name=binet240>Binet, p.240</ref> Providers would span from [[Newcastle]] to [[Saint Petersburg]] and [[Riga]].<ref name=binet240 />

In August 1764, Groignard started laying down parts in Lorient shipyard, hoping to take advantage of the summer weather and of a moment of low activity by the East India Company. However, the fluyts needed to transport construction wood were damaged and a lack of wood and nails soon slowed down the work.<ref name=binet242>Binet, p.242</ref> In December, the Estates and the Company signed an understanding that Groignard would have access to the parts and materials stocked in the Company stores, and that the Estates would replenish them within three months.<ref name=binet243>Binet, p.243</ref> On 12 December, the keel was laid down, the bow had been assembled, and the [[Frame (nautical)
column2: frames]] were made and ready to be installed.<ref name=binet244>Binet, p.244</ref>

column1: However, on 12 January 1765, the Commission ordered that the construction be halted, <ref name=binet244 /> and summoned Groignard to Nantes.<ref name=binet249>Binet, p.249</ref> Realising its lack of competence, the Commission had decided cease procuring material directly and to mandate a harbour for the overall budget of the project, either Lorient or Brest.<ref name=binet250>Binet, p.252</ref> By March, Brest had won the contract; <ref name=binet254>Binet, p.254</ref> the ship was dismantled and her pieces were brought to Brest in May 1765.<ref name=demerliac_1774_15 /> Groignard remained in charge of the work, <ref name=binet254 /> while the Commission was little involved from then on.<ref name=binet255>Binet, p.255</ref>

On 5 July 1765, the keel was laid down in Brest<ref name=binet256>Binet, p.256</ref> in the upper dry dock of Pontaniou.<ref name=forrer15>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.15</ref> By mid-July, the framing was completed.<ref name=binet256 /> By mid-September, the hull was [[Caulk
column2: caulked]].<ref name=binet257>Binet, p.257</ref> In late February 1766, carpenters had completed the [[orlop deck]] and were preparing construction of the [[Gun deck
column3: first battery]].<ref name=binet257 /> In April, the sides were completed up to the lower battery, and the decks of the lower and middle batteries were installed.<ref name=binet258>Binet, p.258</ref> On 24 May 1766, ''Bretagne'' was launched.<ref name=binet258 /><ref name=Roche85 />

column1: Completion of the ship remained slow, <ref name=forrer15 /> and ''Bretagne'' was declared completed on 30 September 1767. <ref name=demerliac_1774_15 /><ref name=forrer15 /> ''Bretagne'' was commissioned in 1768,<ref name=binet261>Binet, p.261</ref> but in June 1770 work remained to be done to make her sea worthy, and she spent the whole year fitting out.<ref name=forrer15 /> On 30 November 1771, she was declared in need of an extensive refit.<ref name=forrer15 />

In 1773, ''Bretagne'' was listed as serving in the Brest Brigade of the Ponant Division of the Navy.<ref name=binet261 /> However, her state was deteriorating, and harbour director Count de Breugnon sent her to a dry dock, where she entered on 9 August.<ref name=forrer15 /> In 1775, [[Louis Guillouet, comte d'Orvilliers
column2: Orvilliers]], took command of the Brest squadron and, finding her timbers rotten, petitionned [[Antoine de Sartine
column3: Sartine]] for an extensive refit;<ref name=binet261 /><ref name=forrer15 />  reconstruction started on 1 September 1776, taking  480,000 pounds, and ''Bretagne'' was launched on 7 April 1777. She took two more months for fitting out.<ref name=forrer15 />
Later, naive representation of the [[Battle of Ushant (1778)
column4: Battle of Ushant]] depicting ''Bretagne'' fighting [[HMS Victory

column3: Representation of ''Bretagne'' circa 1782, [[Peabody Essex Museum]], [[Salem, Massachusetts]].]]

column1: She took part in most of the engagements of the European theatre of the [[Anglo-French War (1778–1783)
column2: Anglo-French War]],<ref name=binet262>Binet, p.262</ref> notably the [[Battle of Ushant (1778)
column3: Battle of Ushant]] in 1778, where she served as [[Louis Guillouet, comte d'Orvilliers
column4: Orvilliers]]' flagship. <ref name=Roche85 /> She took part in the [[Armada of 1779]], but an epidemic aboard forced her to return to Brest in September.<ref name=binet262 /> In 1779, her armament was reinforced by adding 10 further [[6-pounder long gun
column5: 6-pounders]] to her [[quarterdeck]], turning her into a 110-gun.<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> On 2 September 1780, ''Bretagne'' left Brest for Cadiz, where she took part in the [[Great Siege of Gibraltar]].

column1: Although she had good nautical qualities,''Bretagne'' had a tendency to leak and [[Hogging and sagging
column2: hog]], <ref name=forrer20>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.20</ref> and from February to April 1781, she underwent a refit in Brest and notably received a [[copper sheathing]].<ref name=demerliac_1774_15 /> ''Bretagne'' then undertook an expedition under Captain Soulange<ref name=forrer20 /> in [[Luc Urbain de Bouëxic, comte de Guichen
column3: Guichen]]'s squadron in the Mediterranean and the Atlantic from 22 June to early September.<ref name=forrer19>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.19</ref>

column1: After spending three months in Brest, she sailed again on 12 December 1781.<ref name=forrer19 /> She sustained damage in foul weather, <ref name=forrer19 /> notably in a hurricane on 25 and 26 December.<ref name=binet262 /> At her return to Brest, ''Bretagne'' was in need of serious repairs, and Guichen, to his chagrin, had to transfer his flag to [[French ship Terrible (1780)
column2: ''Terrible'']].<ref name=forrer19 /> In 1782, her keel had [[Hogging and sagging
column3: hogged]] by 1'7\" ''pied du roi''.<ref name=demerliac_1774_15 /> ''Bretagne'' was refitted in Brest from 2 March to July 1782,<ref name=demerliac_1792_19>Demerliac, ''1792—1799'', n°1, p. 19</ref> undergoing extensive repairs of her hull but losing her copper sheating in the process.<ref name=forrer20 />

column1: On 8 July 1782,<ref name=forrer20 /> ''Bretagne'' departed Brest under Captain [[Charles Picot de Dampierre]] to join the franco-Spanish combined fleet still [[Great Siege of Gibraltar
column2: besieging Gibraltar]], arriving on 11 along with [[French ship Invincible (1780)
column6: ''Guerrier'']].<ref>Troude, vol.2, p.128</ref> Her cutter rescued men from the crew of the Spanish floating battery ''Talla Piedra'' on 13 September. ''Bretagne'', under Dampierre,<ref>Kerguelen-Trémarec, p.323</ref><ref>Troude, vol.2, p.134</ref> blockaded Gibraltar until 10 October, when a gale damaged her rigging, killing a [[helmsman]] and ripping anchors from the ship. <ref name=forrer20 /> On 13 October 1782, the fleet moved to intercept a British squadron, resulting in the [[Battle of Cape Spartel]] on 20 where ''Bretagne'' sustained 5 men wounded.<ref name=binet262 /><ref name=forrer20 /> ''Bretagne'' then returned to Cadiz harbour in preparation for an expedition to America under [[Charles Henri Hector d'Estaing
column7: Admiral d'Estaing]], but by then the [[Peace of Paris (1783)
column8: Peace of Paris]] had been concluded and ''Bretagne'' returned to Brest.<ref name=forrer20 />

column1: ''Bretagne'' was refitted in Brest in 1788 until the end of the year.<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> The [[poop deck]] was removed to improve stability. <ref name=forrer20 />
''Bretagne'' was refitted in Brest from 1792 to June 1793,<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> 6 [[Obusier de vaisseau
column2: obusiers de vaisseau]] being added that year.<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> ''Bretagne'', under Captain [[Joseph de Richery]], became the flagship of Admiral [[Jean-Amable Lelarge]].<ref>Troude, vol.2, p.287</ref><ref name=forrer21>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.21</ref> In September 1793, her crew was involved in the [[Quibéron mutinies]]; <ref name=Roche85 /> in reaction [[Jeanbon Saint-André]] had Lelarge destitued and Richery arrested,<ref>Troude, vol.2, p.290</ref> and ''Bretagne'' renamed to '''''Révolutionnaire'''''.<ref name=forrer21 />

column1: Captain [[Daniel Vandongen]]<ref>Johnson, p. 96</ref> took command of ''Révolutionnaire'' and put her in good order. By 19 June 1794, she was copperd and fully armed.<ref name=forrer21 />

On 16 May 1794, the fleet departed Brest.<ref name=forrer21 /><ref>Troude, vol.2, p.328</ref>  On 28, the British and French squadrons met, leading to the skirmishes that would culminate into the so-called [[Glorious First of June]].<ref name=Roche85 /> The French line of battle was set in reverse order, and ''Révolutionnaire'' found herself at the rear, last ship in the line.<ref name=forrer21 /> In action against five or six 74-gun ships ([[HMS Russell (1764)
column5: ''Leviathan'']])<ref name=Roche85 /> she was badly damaged, losing all her masts. At 0930,  a shot killed Captain Vandongen,<ref name=forrer21 /> leaving ''Révolutionnaire'' without experienced command as the first lieutenant was wounded and the second lieutenant has already been killed.<ref name=johnson87>Johnson, p.87</ref> Third Lieutenant Renaudeau assumed command but was incapacitated almost immediately as well, and Fourth Lieutenant Dorré took over.<ref name=troude334>Troude, vol.2, p.334</ref> ''Révolutionnaire'' was isolated and defenceless, and avoided captured mostly thanks to [[Richard Howe, 1st Earl Howe
column6: Admiral Howe]]'s order to his ships to regroup.<ref name=forrer21 />{{refn
column7: A rumour states that ''Révolutionnaire'' struck her colours at some point, which her officers disputed.<ref name=forrer21 />
column8: group=Note}} In the night, ''Révolutionnaire'' lost her [[mizen]] and her [[mainmast]]. <ref name=troude334 /> The next day, she met [[French ship Audacieux (1784)
column10: ''Unité'']], of Nielly's squadron; ''Audacieux'' took ''Révolutionnaire'' in tow and brought her to [[Île-d'Aix]], where she arrived on 8 June<ref name=troude334 /> with 160 crewmembers killed or wounded.<ref name=johnson87 />

column1: ''Révolutionnaire'' was fully repaired and rigged anew at Île-d'Aix, which entailed the construction of a workshop specially for that purpose, as well as bringing all parts from [[Rochefort, Charente-Maritime
column2: Rochefort]]. She was ready again on 7 August 1794, and rejoined Brest on 27 of the same month.<ref name=forrer21 />

column1: On 29 December 1794, under Captain Le Gouardun,<ref name=forrer21 /> ''Révolutionnaire''departed Brest for the [[Croisière du Grand Hiver]], where she was very heavily damaged. <ref name=Roche85 /> She limped back to Brest on 2 February 1795, her hull leaking heavily.<ref name=forrer21 />

Too damaged in the [[Croisière du Grand Hiver]] to be repaired,<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> she was struck on 28 January 1796<ref name=demerliac_1774_15 /><ref name=forrer21 /> and broken up between January and May 1796. <ref name=Roche85 />
A scale model of the ''Bretagne'' is on display at Brest naval museum ([[:commons:Category:Model of Bretagne-MnM 13 MG 4
column2: MnM 13 MG 4]]). Admiral [[François-Edmond Pâris]] states that it was built by of under supervision from [[Pierre-Alexandre-Laurent Forfait
column3: Forfait]] around 1780.<ref name=forrer17 /> The model  depicts ''Bretagne'' in her 1777 state (no coppering yet, but already 16 guns on the castles, 10 on the quarterdeck and 6 on the forecastle).<ref name=forrer17>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.17</ref> The ornaments are not quite realistic: the aft is overly decorated compared to the drawings to master sculptor Lubet, and the [[figurehead]] is a woman carrying the arms of Bretagne, reflecting a project that was never realised in reality. The actual figurehead featured a lion carrying the arms of Bretagne.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Maquette de bateau, Bretagne, vaisseau de 100 canons, 1766

column1: ''Bretagne'' is depicted on the painting ''Vue du port de Brest en 1793'' by [[Jean-François Hue]].<ref name=forrer18>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p. 18</ref>

column2: title=Representations of ''Bretagne'' in ''Vue du port de Brest''

column3: ''Vue du port de Brest'' by [[Jean-François Hue]]
''Bretagne'', detail of ''Vue du port de Brest'' by [[Jean-François Hue]]

column1: Claude Forrer published a plan of ''Bretagne'' by master sculptor Lubet in ''Neptunia'' 202 in June 1996.<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> <ref name=forrer16>Forrer, p. 16</ref>

column3: title=La construction du vaisseau de 100 canons \"La Bretagne\"
column4: journal=Annales de Bretagne et des pays de l'Ouest

column2: title=La Marine de Louis XVI: Nomenclature des Navires Français de 1774 à 1792
title=La Marine de la Révolution: Nomenclature des Navires Français de 1792 à 1799
title=Relation des combats et des évènements de la guerre maritime de 1778 entre la France et l'Angleterre

column5: title=Dictionnaire des bâtiments de la flotte de guerre française de Colbert à nos jours

column4: title=La Bretagne : origine d’un nom prestigieux dans la Marine française
title=Louis-Thomas Villaret de Joyeuse: Admiral and colonial administrator (1747-1812)

column1: [[Category:Ships of the line of the French Navy]]

column2: Ship caption=Scale model of the ''Bretagne'' (MnM 13 MG 4), on display at Brest naval museum
Ship flag=[[Image:Flag of the Kingdom of France (1814-1830).svg
Ship renamed=Renamed to ''Révolutionnaire'' in October 1793 <ref name=Roche85 />
Ship sail plan=[[Full rigged ship]], 30.666 square feet<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 />
obusiers de vaisseau]] added in 1793<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 />

column1: '''''Bretagne''''' was a large 110-gun three-decker French [[ship of the line]], built at [[Brest, France
column2: Brest]], which became famous as the flagship of the Brest Fleet during the [[American War of Independence]]. She was funded by a ''[[don des vaisseaux]]'' grant by the [[Estates of Brittany]]. <ref name=Roche85 /> She was active in the European theatres of the [[Anglo-French War (1778–1783)
column3: Anglo-French War]] and of the [[French Revolutionary Wars]], notably taking an important role in the [[Glorious First of June]]. Later, she took part in the  [[Croisière du Grand Hiver]] and was broken up.<ref name=forrer21 />

column1: The [[Seven Years' War]] had left the [[French Navy]] severly depleted, and the Crown did not have funds to replace the ships lost during the conflict. In late 1761 [[Étienne François, duc de Choiseul]] took the direction and proposed that the great institutions of France make voluntary donations, a scheme named ''[[don des vaisseaux]]''. On 1 September 1762,<ref name=nomprestigieux>{{cite web
column4: title=La Bretagne : origine d’un nom prestigieux dans la Marine française
column9: date=1 February 2019}}</ref> the [[Estates of Brittany]] gathered at the Couvent des Cordeliers in Rennes<ref name=binet212>Binet, p.212</ref> and decided to raise one million [[Livre tournois
column10: Livres tournois]] in order to offer a 100-gun [[Three-decker]].<ref name=binet211>Binet, p.211</ref> [[Ship-of-the-line lieutenant
column11: Lieutenant]] Jean-Claude Louis de Quelen rode to [[Choisy-le-Roi]]<ref name=binet215>Binet, p.215</ref> to inform [[Louis XV of France
column12: Louis XV]], arriving on 5 and returning on 9 with acceptance letters from the King and from the Duke de Choiseul.<ref name=nomprestigieux /> Administrative dispositions for a load started on 2 November, and were completed by 17.<ref name=binet217>Binet, p.217</ref> Budget would eventually reach  1,010,000 [[Livre tournois

column1: The donation had political connotations, both in terms of rivalry between the various donating institutions, and for the status of Bretagne within France.<ref name=forrer13>Forrer, p. 13</ref> Therefore, the Estates of Brittany attached their gift to a number of requests: that the ship be named ''Bretagne'' rather than ''États de Bretagne'', that the crew be composed of Bretons exlusively, and that the ship be a three-decker.<ref name=binet213>Binet, p.213</ref> Furthermore, rather than donate funds that the Crown would invest in construction, the Estates demanded to supervise construction themselves at the shipyards of the [[French East India Company]] in [[Lorient]].<ref name=nomprestigieux /><ref name=binet211 />

On 2 November 1761, the Commission of the Estates of Brittany in charge of construction mandated [[Antoine Groignard]] as chief engineer, with Gaubry as deputy and Damel as an advisor.<ref name=binet218>Binet, p.218</ref> Groignard worked both for the French Royal Navy and for the French East India Company; he had recently directed the construction of the 80-gun [[French ship Orient (1756)
column5: ''Solitaire'']], and was supervising ongoing construction of the 74-gun [[French ship Diligent (1763)
column8: ''Bordelois'']] in Lorient, that of the 56-gun [[French ship Utile (1764)
column11: ''Flamand'']] in [[Bordeaux]], and four frigates in Nantes.<ref name=binet219>Binet, p.219</ref>

column1: On 17 November 1761, Groignard sent of proposal for a budget between 919,000 and 1,115,000 pounds.<ref name=binet220>Binet, p.220</ref> The shipyards in Lorient received their first orders in early December.<ref name=binet221>Binet, p.221</ref> Choiseul wrote the Groignard to congratulate him for his appointment, and to argue in favour of building a 80-gun two-decker, with [[36-pounder long gun
column2: 36-pounders]] on the lower battery and [[24-pounder long gun
column3: 24-pounders]] on the upper, although he conceded that political considerations mandated a three-decker. He also reminded of the shortcomings of [[French ship Royal Louis (1759)
column4: ''Royal Louis'']], an unsuccessful 100-gun of the time.<ref name=binet222>Binet, p.222</ref>

column1: Groignard hoped to complete construction by 1763, but delay in complete the 1-million load and difficulties in stocking construction wood soon set the schedule back. On 28 March 1763, Groignard sent completed plans to the construction commission, which failed to forward them to Choiseul. On 6 May, Choiseul wrote directly to Groignard to enquire, and setting further requirements that the artillery be set on the three batteries (limiting armament of the castles),<ref name=forrer14>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.14</ref> and that autonomy be sufficient to feed 1,000 men for six months, with water for two.<ref name=binet223>Binet, p.223</ref> By July, construction was expected to be completed in 1765,<ref name=binet225>Binet, p.225</ref> and there were several exchanges of letters and budget estimations between various administrations and rival naval engineers, second-guessing Groignard and arguing about the furniture and spare parts needed for the ship.<ref name=binet228>Binet, p.228</ref>

column4: Depiction on ''Bretagne'' flying the white ensign of the [[Ancien Régime]].]]

column1: By 3 January 1764, the Commission was requesting revised versions of the plans as to reduce the dimensions of ''Bretagne''.<ref name=binet231>Binet, p.231</ref> On 23, Groignard submitted his new plans, along with a memorandum underlining that this version would now allow the ship to hold six month worth of food and was compromising her stability, speed and manœuverability.<ref name=binet235>Binet, p.235</ref> On 19 February, Choiseul declined to approve the revised plans and requested a third version; Groignard completed quickly and went directly to Paris himself to submit them, short-circuiting the construction Commission of the Estates of Brittany<ref name=binet237>Binet, p.237</ref> and talking Choiseul out of the notion that the lower battery should be armed with 24-pounders instead of 36-pounders.<ref name=binet238>Binet, p.238</ref><ref name=forrer14 /> On 7 May, Choiseul informed the Commission that his plans had met with approval and that the construction could begin.<ref name=binet238 />

The Commission then started procuring the raw materials needed for the construction, notably wood, fabric for the sails, iron and cables. Lacking experience in the matter, it requested advice from Roth, director of the East India Company in Lorient,<ref name=forrer14 /> who replied on 1 April with a long memorandum.<ref name=binet239>Binet, p.239</ref> Besides explaining how to assess the quality of the materials, how to transport it on land and how to store it, the memorandum observed that a number of parts would need to be obtained from outside of Bretagne, and sometimes even abroard, notably from the Netherlands.<ref name=binet240>Binet, p.240</ref> Providers would span from [[Newcastle]] to [[Saint Petersburg]] and [[Riga]].<ref name=binet240 />

However, the fluyts needed to transport construction wood were damaged and a lack of wood and nails soon slowed down the work.<ref name=binet242>Binet, p.242</ref> In December, the Estates and the Company signed an understanding that Groignard would have access to the parts and materials stocked in the Company stores, and that the Estates would replenish them within three months.<ref name=binet243>Binet, p.243</ref> On 12 December, the keel was laid down, the bow had been assembled, and the [[Frame (nautical)
column2: frames]] were made and ready to be installed.<ref name=binet244>Binet, p.244</ref>

On 5 July 1765, the keel was laid down in Brest<ref name=binet256>Binet, p.256</ref> in the upper dry dock of Pontaniou.<ref name=forrer15>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.15</ref> By mid-July, the framing was completed.<ref name=binet256 /> By mid-September, the hull was [[Caulk
column2: caulked]].<ref name=binet257>Binet, p.257</ref> In late February 1766, carpenters had completed the [[orlop deck]] and were preparing construction of the [[Gun deck
column3: first battery]].<ref name=binet257 /> In April, the sides were completed up to the lower battery, and the decks of the lower and middle batteries were installed.<ref name=binet258>Binet, p.258</ref> On 24 May 1766, ''Bretagne'' was launched.<ref name=binet258 /><ref name=Roche85 />

column3: Sartine]] for an extensive refit;<ref name=binet261 /><ref name=forrer15 />  reconstruction started on 1 September 1776, taking  480,000 pounds, and ''Bretagne'' was launched on 7 April 1777. She took two more months for fitting out.<ref name=forrer15 />

column2: hog]], <ref name=forrer20>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.20</ref> and from February to April 1781, she underwent a refit in Brest and notably received a [[copper sheathing]].<ref name=demerliac_1774_15 /> ''Bretagne'' then undertook an expedition under Captain Soulange<ref name=forrer20 /> in [[Luc Urbain de Bouëxic, comte de Guichen
column3: Guichen]]'s squadron in the Mediterranean and the Atlantic from 22 June to early September.<ref name=forrer19>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.19</ref>

column1: After spending three months in Brest, she sailed again on 12 December 1781.<ref name=forrer19 /> She sustained damage in foul weather, <ref name=forrer19 /> notably in a hurricane on 25 and 26 December.<ref name=binet262 /> At her return to Brest, ''Bretagne'' was in need of serious repairs, and Guichen, to his chagrin, had to transfer his flag to [[French ship Terrible (1780)
column2: ''Terrible'']].<ref name=forrer19 /> In 1782, her keel had [[Hogging and sagging
column3: hogged]] by 1'7\" ''pied du roi''.<ref name=demerliac_1774_15 /> ''Bretagne'' was refitted in Brest from 2 March to July 1782,<ref name=demerliac_1792_19>Demerliac, ''1792—1799'', n°1, p. 19</ref> undergoing extensive repairs of her hull but losing her copper sheating in the process.<ref name=forrer20 />

column1: On 8 July 1782,<ref name=forrer20 /> ''Bretagne'' departed Brest under Captain [[Charles Picot de Dampierre]] to join the franco-Spanish combined fleet still [[Great Siege of Gibraltar
column2: besieging Gibraltar]], arriving on 11 along with [[French ship Invincible (1780)
column6: ''Guerrier'']].<ref>Troude, vol.2, p.128</ref> Her cutter rescued men from the crew of the Spanish floating battery ''Talla Piedra'' on 13 September. ''Bretagne'', under Dampierre,<ref>Kerguelen-Trémarec, p.323</ref><ref>Troude, vol.2, p.134</ref> blockaded Gibraltar until 10 October, when a gale damaged her rigging, killing a [[helmsman]] and ripping anchors from the ship. <ref name=forrer20 /> On 13 October 1782, the fleet moved to intercept a British squadron, resulting in the [[Battle of Cape Spartel]] on 20 where ''Bretagne'' sustained 5 men wounded.<ref name=binet262 /><ref name=forrer20 /> ''Bretagne'' then returned to Cadiz harbour in preparation for an expedition to America under [[Charles Henri Hector d'Estaing
column7: Admiral d'Estaing]], but by then the [[Peace of Paris (1783)
column8: Peace of Paris]] had been concluded and ''Bretagne'' returned to Brest.<ref name=forrer20 />

column1: ''Bretagne'' was refitted in Brest in 1788 until the end of the year.<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> The [[poop deck]] was removed to improve stability. <ref name=forrer20 />
''Bretagne'' was refitted in Brest from 1792 to June 1793,<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> 6 [[Obusier de vaisseau
column2: obusiers de vaisseau]] being added that year.<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> ''Bretagne'', under Captain [[Joseph de Richery]], became the flagship of Admiral [[Jean-Amable Lelarge]].<ref>Troude, vol.2, p.287</ref><ref name=forrer21>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.21</ref> In September 1793, her crew was involved in the [[Quibéron mutinies]]; <ref name=Roche85 /> in reaction [[Jeanbon Saint-André]] had Lelarge destitued and Richery arrested,<ref>Troude, vol.2, p.290</ref> and ''Bretagne'' renamed to '''''Révolutionnaire'''''.<ref name=forrer21 />

column1: Captain [[Daniel Vandongen]]<ref>Johnson, p. 96</ref> took command of ''Révolutionnaire'' and put her in good order. By 19 June 1794, she was copperd and fully armed.<ref name=forrer21 />

On 16 Mai 1794, the fleet departed Brest.<ref name=forrer21 /><ref>Troude, vol.2, p.328</ref>  On 28, the British and French squadrons met, leading to the skirmishes that would culminate into the so-called [[Glorious First of June]].<ref name=Roche85 /> The French line of battle was set in reverse order, and ''Révolutionnaire'' found herself at the rear, last ship in the line.<ref name=forrer21 /> In action against five or six 74-gun ships ([[HMS Russell (1764)
column5: ''Leviathan'']])<ref name=Roche85 /> she was badly damaged, losing all her masts. At 0930,  a shot killed Captain Vandongen,<ref name=forrer21 /> leaving ''Révolutionnaire'' without experienced command as the first lieutenant was wounded and the second lieutenant has already been killed.<ref name=johnson87>Johnson, p.87</ref> Third Lieutenant Renaudeau assumed command but was incapacitated almost immediately as well, and Fourth Lieutenant Dorré took over.<ref name=troude334>Troude, vol.2, p.334</ref> ''Révolutionnaire'' was isolated and defenceless, and avoided captured mostly thanks to [[Richard Howe, 1st Earl Howe
column6: Admiral Howe]]'s order to his ships to regroup.<ref name=forrer21 />{{refn
column7: A rumour states that ''Révolutionnaire'' struck her colours at some point, which her officers disputed.<ref name=forrer21 />
column8: group=Note}} In the night, ''Révolutionnaire'' lost her [[mizen]] and her [[mainmast]]. <ref name=troude334 /> The next day, she met [[French ship Audacieux (1784)
column10: ''Unité'']], of Nielly's squadron; ''Audacieux'' took ''Révolutionnaire'' in tow and brought her to [[Île-d'Aix]], where she arrived on 8 June<ref name=troude334 /> with 160 crewmembers killed or wounded.<ref name=johnson87 />

column1: ''Révolutionnaire'' was fully repaired and rigged anew at Île-d'Aix, which entailed the construction of a workshop specially for that purpose, as well as bringing all parts from [[Rochefort, Charente-Maritime
column2: Rochefort]]. She was ready again on 7 August 1794, and rejoined Brest on 27 of the same month.<ref name=forrer21 />

column1: On 29 December 1794, under Captain Le Gouardun,<ref name=forrer21 /> ''Révolutionnaire''departed Brest for the [[Croisière du Grand Hiver]], where she was very heavily damaged. <ref name=Roche85 /> She limped back to Brest on 2 February 1795, her hull leaking heavily.<ref name=forrer21 />

Too damaged in the [[Croisière du Grand Hiver]] to be repaired,<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> she was struck on 28 January 1796<ref name=demerliac_1774_15 /><ref name=forrer21 /> and broken up between January and May 1796. <ref name=Roche85 />
A scale model of the ''Bretagne'' is on display at Brest naval museum ([[:commons:Category:Model of Bretagne-MnM 13 MG 4
column2: MnM 13 MG 4]]). Admiral [[François-Edmond Pâris]] states that it was built by of under supervision from [[Pierre-Alexandre-Laurent Forfait
column3: Forfait]] around 1780.<ref name=forrer17 /> The model  depicts ''Bretagne'' in her 1777 state (no coppering yet, but already 16 guns on the castles, 10 on the quarterdeck and 6 on the forecastle).<ref name=forrer17>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.17</ref> The ornaments are not quite realistic: the aft is overly decorated compared to the drawings to master sculptor Lubet, and the [[figurehead]] is a woman carrying the arms of Bretagne, reflecting a project that was never realised in reality. The actual figurehead featured a lion carrying the arms of Bretagne.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Maquette de bateau, Bretagne, vaisseau de 100 canons, 1766

column1: ''Bretagne'' is depicted on the painting ''Vue du port de Brest en 1793'' by [[Jean-François Hue]].<ref name=forrer18>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p. 18</ref>

column2: title=Representations of ''Bretagne'' in ''Vue du port de Brest''

column3: ''Vue du port de Brest'' by [[Jean-François Hue]]
''Bretagne'', detail of ''Vue du port de Brest'' by [[Jean-François Hue]]

column1: Claude Forrer published a plan of ''Bretagne'' by master sculptor Lubet in ''Neptunia'' 202 in June 1996.<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> <ref name=forrer16>Forrer, p. 16</ref>

title=La Marine de la Révolution: Nomenclature des Navires Français de 1792 à 1799

Ship renamed=Renamed to ''Révolutionnaire'' in October 1793 <ref name=Roche85 />
Ship sail plan=[[Full rigged ship]], 30.666 square feet<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 />
obusiers de vaisseau]] added in 1793<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 />

column1: '''''Bretagne''''' was a large 110-gun three-decker French [[ship of the line]], built at [[Brest, France
column2: Brest]], which became famous as the flagship of the Brest Fleet during the [[American War of Independence]]. She was funded by a ''[[don des vaisseaux]]'' grant by the [[Estates of Brittany]]. <ref name=Roche85 /> She was active in the European theatres of the [[Anglo-French War (1778–1783)
column3: Anglo-French War]] and of the [[French Revolutionary Wars]], notably taking an important role in the [[Glorious First of June]]. Later, she took part in the  [[Croisière du Grand Hiver]] and was broken up.<ref name=forrer21 />

column1: The [[Seven Years' War]] had left the [[French Navy]] severly depleted, and the Crown did not have funds to replace the ships lost during the conflict. In late 1761 [[Étienne François, duc de Choiseul]] took the direction and proposed that the great institutions of France make voluntary donations, a scheme named ''[[don des vaisseaux]]''. On 1 September 1762,<ref name=nomprestigieux>{{cite web
column4: title=La Bretagne : origine d’un nom prestigieux dans la Marine française
column9: date=1 February 2019}}</ref> the [[Estates of Brittany]] gathered at the Couvent des Cordeliers in Rennes<ref name=binet212>Binet, p.212</ref> and decided to raise one million [[Livre tournois
column10: Livres tournois]] in order to offer a 100-gun [[Three-decker]].<ref name=binet211>Binet, p.211</ref> [[Ship-of-the-line lieutenant
column11: Lieutenant]] Jean-Claude Louis de Quelen rode to [[Choisy-le-Roi]]<ref name=binet215>Binet, p.215</ref> to inform [[Louis XV of France
column12: Louis XV]], arriving on 5 and returning on 9 with acceptance letters from the King and from the Duke de Choiseul.<ref name=nomprestigieux /> Administrative dispositions for a load started on 2 November, and were completed by 17.<ref name=binet217>Binet, p.217</ref> Budget would eventually reach  1,010,000 [[Livre tournois

column1: The donation had political connotations, both in terms of rivalry between the various donating institutions, and for the status of Bretagne within France.<ref name=forrer13>Forrer, p. 13</ref> Therefore, the Estates of Brittany attached their gift to a number of requests: that the ship be named ''Bretagne'' rather than ''États de Bretagne'', that the crew be composed of Bretons exlusively, and that the ship be a three-decker.<ref name=binet213>Binet, p.213</ref> Furthermore, rather than donate funds that the Crown would invest in construction, the Estates demanded to supervise construction themselves at the shipyards of the [[French East India Company]] in [[Lorient]].<ref name=nomprestigieux /><ref name=binet211 />

On 2 November 1761, the Commission of the Estates of Brittany in charge of construction mandated [[Antoine Groignard]] as chief engineer, with Gaubry as deputy and Damel as an advisor.<ref name=binet218>Binet, p.218</ref> Groignard worked both for the French Royal Navy and for the French East India Company; he had recently directed the construction of the 80-gun [[French ship Orient (1756)
column5: ''Solitaire'']], and was supervising ongoing construction of the 74-gun [[French ship Diligent (1763)
column8: ''Bordelois'']] in Lorient, that of the 56-gun [[French ship Utile (1764)
column11: ''Flamand'']] in [[Bordeaux]], and four frigates in Nantes.<ref name=binet219>Binet, p.219</ref>

column1: On 17 November 1761, Groignard sent of proposal for a budget between 919,000 and 1,115,000 pounds.<ref name=binet220>Binet, p.220</ref> The shipyards in Lorient received their first orders in early December.<ref name=binet221>Binet, p.221</ref> Choiseul wrote the Groignard to congratulate him for his appointment, and to argue in favour of building a 80-gun two-decker, with [[36-pounder long gun
column2: 36-pounders]] on the lower battery and [[24-pounder long gun
column3: 24-pounders]] on the upper, although he conceded that political considerations mandated a three-decker. He also reminded of the shortcomings of [[French ship Royal Louis (1759)
column4: ''Royal Louis'']], an unsuccessful 100-gun of the time.<ref name=binet222>Binet, p.222</ref>

column1: Groignard hoped to complete construction by 1763, but delay in complete the 1-million load and difficulties in stocking construction wood soon set the schedule back. On 28 March 1763, Groignard sent completed plans to the construction commission, which failed to forward them to Choiseul. On 6 May, Choiseul wrote directly to Groignard to enquire, and setting further requirements that the artillery be set on the three batteries (limiting armament of the castles),<ref name=forrer14>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.14</ref> and that autonomy be sufficient to feed 1,000 men for six months, with water for two.<ref name=binet223>Binet, p.223</ref> By July, construction was expected to be completed in 1765,<ref name=binet225>Binet, p.225</ref> and there were several exchanges of letters and budget estimations between various administrations and rival naval engineers, second-guessing Groignard and arguing about the furniture and spare parts needed for the ship.<ref name=binet228>Binet, p.228</ref>

column4: Depiction on ''Bretagne'' flying the white ensign of the [[Ancien Régime]].]]

column1: By 3 January 1764, the Commission was requesting revised versions of the plans as to reduce the dimensions of ''Bretagne''.<ref name=binet231>Binet, p.231</ref> On 23, Groignard submitted his new plans, along with a memorandum underlining that this version would now allow the ship to hold six month worth of food and was compromising her stability, speed and manœuverability.<ref name=binet235>Binet, p.235</ref> On 19 February, Choiseul declined to approve the revised plans and requested a third version; Groignard completed quickly and went directly to Paris himself to submit them, short-circuiting the construction Commission of the Estates of Brittany<ref name=binet237>Binet, p.237</ref> and talking Choiseul out of the notion that the lower battery should be armed with 24-pounders instead of 36-pounders.<ref name=binet238>Binet, p.238</ref><ref name=forrer14 /> On 7 May, Choiseul informed the Commission that his plans had met with approval and that the construction could begin.<ref name=binet238 />

The Commission then started procuring the raw materials needed for the construction, notably wood, fabric for the sails, iron and cables. Lacking experience in the matter, it requested advice from Roth, director of the East India Company in Lorient,<ref name=forrer14 /> who replied on 1 April with a long memorandum.<ref name=binet239>Binet, p.239</ref> Besides explaining how to assess the quality of the materials, how to transport it on land and how to store it, the memorandum observed that a number of parts would need to be obtained from outside of Bretagne, and sometimes even abroard, notably from the Netherlands.<ref name=binet240>Binet, p.240</ref> Providers would span from [[Newcastle]] to [[Saint Petersburg]] and [[Riga]].<ref name=binet240 />

In August 1764, Groignard started laying down parts in Lorient shipyard, hoping to take advantage of the summer weather and of a moment of low activity by the East India Company. However, the fluyts needed to transport construction wood were damaged and a lack of wood and nails soon slowed down the work.<ref name=binet242>Binet, p.242</ref> In December, the Estates and the Company signed an understanding that Groignard would have access to the parts and materials stocked in the Company stores, and that the Estates would replenish them within three months.<ref name=binet243>Binet, p.243</ref> On 12 December, the keel was laid down, the bow had been assembled, and the [[Frame (nautical)
column2: frames]] were made and ready to be installed.<ref name=binet244>Binet, p.244</ref>

column1: However, on 12 January 1765, the Commission ordered that the construction be halted, <ref name=binet244 /> and summoned Groignard to Nantes.<ref name=binet249>Binet, p.249</ref> Realising its lack of competence, the Commission had decided cease procuring material directly and to mandate a harbour for the overall budget of the project, either Lorient or Brest.<ref name=binet250>Binet, p.252</ref> By March, Brest had won the contract; <ref name=binet254>Binet, p.254</ref> the ship was dismantled and her pieces were brought to Brest in May 1765.<ref name=demerliac_1774_15 /> Groignard remained in charge of the work, <ref name=binet254 /> while the Commission was little involved from then on.<ref name=binet255>Binet, p.255</ref>

On 5 July 1765, the keel was laid down in Brest<ref name=binet256>Binet, p.256</ref> in the upper dry dock of Pontaniou.<ref name=forrer15>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.15</ref> By mid-July, the framing was completed.<ref name=binet256 /> By mid-September, the hull was [[Caulk
column2: caulked]].<ref name=binet257>Binet, p.257</ref> In late February 1766, carpenters had completed the [[orlop deck]] and were preparing construction of the [[Gun deck
column3: first battery]].<ref name=binet257 /> In April, the sides were completed up to the lower battery, and the decks of the lower and middle batteries were installed.<ref name=binet258>Binet, p.258</ref> On 24 May 1766, ''Bretagne'' was launched.<ref name=binet258 /><ref name=Roche85 />

column1: Completion of the ship remained slow, <ref name=forrer15 /> and ''Bretagne'' was declared completed on 30 September 1767. <ref name=demerliac_1774_15 /><ref name=forrer15 /> ''Bretagne'' was commissioned in 1768,<ref name=binet261>Binet, p.261</ref> but in June 1770 work remained to be done to make her sea worthy, and she spent the whole year fitting out.<ref name=forrer15 /> On 30 November 1771, she was declared in need of an extensive refit.<ref name=forrer15 />

In 1773, ''Bretagne'' was listed as serving in the Brest Brigade of the Ponant Division of the Navy.<ref name=binet261 /> However, her state was deteriorating, and harbour director Count de Breugnon sent her to a dry dock, where she entered on 9 August.<ref name=forrer15 /> In 1775, [[Louis Guillouet, comte d'Orvilliers
column2: Orvilliers]], took command of the Brest squadron and, finding her timbers rotten, petitionned [[Antoine de Sartine
column3: Sartine]] for an extensive refit;<ref name=binet261 /><ref name=forrer15 />  reconstruction started on 1 September 1776, taking  480,000 pounds, and ''Bretagne'' was launched on 7 April 1777. She took two more months for fitting out.<ref name=forrer15 />
Later, naive representation of the [[Battle of Ushant (1778)
column4: Battle of Ushant]] depicting ''Bretagne'' fighting [[HMS Victory

column3: Representation of ''Bretagne'' circa 1782, [[Peabody Essex Museum]], [[Salem, Massachusetts]].]]

column1: She took part in most of the engagements of the European theatre of the [[Anglo-French War (1778–1783)
column2: Anglo-French War]],<ref name=binet262>Binet, p.262</ref> notably the [[Battle of Ushant (1778)
column3: Battle of Ushant]] in 1778, where she served as [[Louis Guillouet, comte d'Orvilliers
column4: Orvilliers]]' flagship. <ref name=Roche85 /> She took part in the [[Armada of 1779]], but an epidemic aboard forced her to return to Brest in September.<ref name=binet262 /> In 1779, her armament was reinforced by adding 10 further [[6-pounder long gun
column5: 6-pounders]] to her [[quarterdeck]], turning her into a 110-gun.<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> On 2 September 1780, ''Bretagne'' left Brest for Cadiz, where she took part in the [[Great Siege of Gibraltar]].

column1: Although she had good nautical qualities,''Bretagne'' had a tendency to leak and [[Hogging and sagging
column2: hog]], <ref name=forrer20>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.20</ref> and from February to April 1781, she underwent a refit in Brest and notably received a [[copper sheathing]].<ref name=demerliac_1774_15 /> ''Bretagne'' then undertook an expedition under Captain Soulange<ref name=forrer20 /> in [[Luc Urbain de Bouëxic, comte de Guichen
column3: Guichen]]'s squadron in the Mediterranean and the Atlantic from 22 June to early September.<ref name=forrer19>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.19</ref>

column2: ''Terrible'']].<ref name=forrer19 /> In 1782, her keel had [[Hogging and sagging
column3: hogged]] by 1'7\" ''pied du roi''.<ref name=demerliac_1774_15 /> ''Bretagne'' was refitted in Brest from 2 March to July 1782,<ref name=demerliac_1792_19>Demerliac, ''1792—1799'', n°1, p. 19</ref> undergoing extensive repairs of her hull but losing her copper sheating in the process.<ref name=forrer20 />

column2: besieging Gibraltar]], arriving on 11 along with [[French ship Invincible (1780)
column6: ''Guerrier'']].<ref>Troude, vol.2, p.128</ref> Her cutter rescued men from the crew of the Spanish floating battery ''Talla Piedra'' on 13 September. ''Bretagne'', under Dampierre,<ref>Kerguelen-Trémarec, p.323</ref><ref>Troude, vol.2, p.134</ref> blockaded Gibraltar until 10 October, when a gale damaged her rigging, killing a [[helmsman]] and ripping anchors from the ship. <ref name=forrer20 /> On 13 October 1782, the fleet moved to intercept a British squadron, resulting in the [[Battle of Cape Spartel]] on 20 where ''Bretagne'' sustained 5 men wounded.<ref name=binet262 /><ref name=forrer20 /> ''Bretagne'' then returned to Cadiz harbour in preparation for an expedition to America under [[Charles Henri Hector d'Estaing
column7: Admiral d'Estaing]], but by then the [[Peace of Paris (1783)
column8: Peace of Paris]] had been concluded and ''Bretagne'' returned to Brest.<ref name=forrer20 />

''Bretagne'' was refitted in Brest from 1792 to June 1793,<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> 6 [[Obusier de vaisseau
column2: obusiers de vaisseau]] being added that year.<ref name=demerliac_1792_19 /> ''Bretagne'', under Captain [[Joseph de Richery]], became the flagship of Admiral [[Jean-Amable Lelarge]].<ref>Troude, vol.2, p.287</ref><ref name=forrer21>Forrer, ''Neptunia'' 202, p.21</ref> In September 1793, her crew was involved in the [[Quibéron mutinies]]; <ref name=Roche85 /> in reaction [[Jeanbon Saint-André]] had Lelarge destitued and Richery arrested,<ref>Troude, vol.2, p.290</ref> and ''Bretagne'' renamed to '''''Révolutionnaire'''''.<ref name=forrer21 />

column3: Strafford County]], [[New Hampshire]], United States. The population was 14,638 at the 2010 census.<ref name=2010Census>United States Census Bureau, [https://www.census.gov U.S. Census website] , 2010 Census figures. Retrieved March 23, 2011.</ref> Durham is home to the [[University of New Hampshire]].

column1: The primary settlement in the town, where 10,345 people resided at the 2010 census,<ref name=\"2010Census\"/> is defined by the U.S. Census Bureau as the [[Durham (CDP), New Hampshire
column2: Durham census-designated place]] (CDP) and includes the densely populated portion of the town centered on the intersection of [[New Hampshire Route 108]] and Main Street, which includes the university that dominates the town.
Great Bay]] at the mouth of the [[Oyster River (New Hampshire)
column3: Oyster River]], Durham was originally called \"Oyster River Plantation\". It was settled in 1635 by pioneers who traveled up the [[Piscataqua River]] and across Little Bay to settle at the falls of the Oyster River.

column1: At the time, the land that is now New Hampshire belonged to Massachusetts; not until 1692 did the [[Province of New Hampshire
column2: New Hampshire colony]] finally gain full and permanent independence from its southern neighbor. Most of the coastal area was divided among four townships, and for its first century, Durham was part of [[Dover, New Hampshire
column3: Dover]]. The location was ideal for its fresh water, natural meadows for livestock, and the transportation opportunities afforded by the waterways leading to the [[Atlantic Ocean]]. The land along the river was quickly settled, and nearby dense forests provided the timber necessary to construct homes as well as boats. Oyster River Plantation took the form of a small agricultural village, and the first generation of residents worked to clear and shape the land for planting.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: The town name \"Durham\" was suggested by the Rev. Hugh Adams, as claimed by him in an address to the General Assembly in 1738.<ref>''N.H. Province Papers'', Vol. V, page 35</ref><ref>Mary P. Thompson, [https://books.google.com/books?id=QarkVaNCBvEC&pg=PA282&lpg=PA282&dq=Mary+P.+Thompson%27s+Landmarks+in+Ancient+Dover,+p.+67.&source=bl&ots=rXTLCrmIF1&sig=hfGsgNxRcAnY_TGtBdJBaaH1IzA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjLtPrQx97JAhVFzIMKHcSdAPcQ6AEIKTAC#v=onepage&q=Rev%2C%20HUgh%20Adams&f=falseMary P. Thompson's Landmarks in Ancient Dover, p. 67 ''Landmarks in Ancient Dover''], p. 67</ref> Two of the earliest settlers of Dover were William and Edward Hilton, the direct descendants of Sir William de Hilton, Lord of [[Hylton Castle
column2: Hilton Castle]] in [[County Durham]], England, but there is nothing to prove that Durham was named in their honor.{{Citation needed

column1: During [[King William's War]], on July 18, 1694, the English settlement was attacked in the [[Raid on Oyster River]] by French career soldier [[Claude-Sébastien de Villieu]] with about 250 [[Abenaki]] from [[Norridgewock]] under command of their [[sachem
column2: sagamore]] Bomazeen (or Bomoseen). In all, 104 inhabitants were killed and 27 taken captive,<ref>Webster, John Clarence. ''Acadia at the End of the Seventeenth Century''. [[Saint John, NB]], New Brunswick Museum, 1979. p. 65</ref> with half the dwellings, including the [[garrison]]s, pillaged and burned to the ground.

column1: The community rebuilt, however, and by 1716 Durham was a separate [[parish]].{{citation needed
column2: date=December 2010}} Incorporated in 1732, Durham at first included portions of the present-day towns of [[Madbury, New Hampshire
column6: date=December 2010}} Because of its [[arable land]], the town would develop as a [[farming]] community.

column2: Benjamin Thompson]], a descendant of an early settler, bequeathed his assets and family estate, Warner Farm, to the state for the establishment of an agricultural college.<ref>{{Cite book
column4: title=The land in our hands: Burley-Demeritt Farm in Lee, NH : its history.
column13: title=Will of Benjamin Thompson - University of New Hampshire Library
column18: archivedate=20 October 2017}}</ref> Founded in 1866 in [[Hanover, New Hampshire
column19: Hanover]], the [[New Hampshire College of Agriculture and the Mechanic Arts]] moved to Durham in 1893 and became the University of New Hampshire in 1923. Thompson Hall, built in 1892 with an iconic [[clock tower]], is named in his honor. Designed in the [[Romanesque Revival]] style by the [[Concord, New Hampshire
column20: Concord]] architectural firm of [[Dow & Randlett]], it was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1996.<ref>{{Cite web
column22: title=National Register of Historic Places Listings -- December 13, 1996

column1: In 2017, Durham became the first community in New Hampshire to recognize [[Indigenous Peoples' Day]] in place of [[Columbus Day]].<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Durham to celebrate Indigenous Peoples' Day on Columbus Day {{!}} New Hampshire
column6: language=en}}</ref> In 2018, the [[Oyster River Cooperative School District]], which includes Durham, Lee and Madbury, adopted Indigenous Peoples' Day on its school calendar.<ref>{{Cite news
column8: title=Oyster River Cooperative School District Adopts Indigenous People's Day

column1: Over the years the people of Durham have created several libraries:
Durham Social Library (1815-1857): This library was incorporated by act of the New Hampshire Legislature in 1815. The library contained several hundred books and had a membership numbering nearly 50.
Durham Agricultural Library (1862-1881): Formed Feb. 3, 1862, with [[Benjamin Thompson (farmer)
column2: Benjamin Thompson]] as president, this library was small (approximately 72 books) and vocationally-based.

column1: Durham Social Library (1881-1892): Organized March 9, 1881, the library had a membership of 80 and several hundred books. In 1883 the Richardson house was purchased to house the library. It eventually merged with the Durham Public Library.

Durham Public Library (1892-1906): Established in 1892 through the provisions of a New Hampshire state act, this was the town's first \"public\" library. It contained more than 3,500 books and eventually merged with the library of the New Hampshire College of Agriculture and the Mechanic Arts.

Library of the New Hampshire College of Agriculture and the Mechanic Arts (1893- ): Came to Durham with the arrival of the College in 1893. Initially, the College housed the library in a single room in Thompson Hall. In 1900 Hamilton Smith gave the University $10,000 to construct a library, another $20,000 was obtained from Andrew Carnegie. In 1907 – a year after the town and the college agreed to merge their collective library resources – the building (Hamilton Smith Hall) was completed.<ref>{{Cite web

In March 1997 by a margin of 2-1, Durham voters passed a charter amendment to establish a Board of Trustees and allow plans for a new library to go forward. In July 1997 a temporary space was found for the new Public Library in a storefront between the dollar store and a pizzeria. Under the guidance of the Trustees and a newly formed Friends of the Library group, many volunteer townspeople come forward to sheetrock, paint, assemble shelves, and unpack and shelve 719 boxes of books. On July 21, 1997 a dedication ceremony was held for the new library, with Governor Jeanne Shaheen as the keynote speaker. It was the first new public library to be established in New Hampshire in almost a century. In July 2013 a new public library building was completed on Madbury Road.
A police force of some manner has served Durham since at least 1848.<ref>{{cite web
column8: archivedate=July 20, 2011 }}</ref> Durham Police Department is made up of 20 full-time and part-time officers and provides service 24-hours a day.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=A Welcome from the Chief of Police

column1: The Police Department's Adopt-A-Cop program was instituted in 1999 to improve relationships between University of New Hampshire fraternities. Each fraternity is assigned a police officer who attends house meetings and events and acts a liaison between the fraternity and the community.<ref>{{cite web
The first fire department organization in Durham was organized in 1927 and the first salaried firefighter was employed in 1934.<ref name=\"FireDept\"/>
The Durham Fire Department is one of the few fire departments in the country that is funded by both a municipality and a university.<ref name=\"FireDept\">{{cite web
In addition, McGregor Memorial EMS is a regional, non-profit organization delivering emergency medical services and education to the New Hampshire Seacoast area since 1968.
According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the town has a total area of {{convert
column12: abbr=on}} is water, comprising 9.57% of the town. The town is drained by the [[Oyster River (New Hampshire)
column13: Oyster River]]. The highest point in Durham is Beech Hill, at {{convert
column16: m}} above [[sea level]], located on the town's northern border.<ref name=topomap>U.S. Geological Survey. Dover Quadrangle, New Hampshire-Maine map. 1:62,500. 15 Minute Series (Topographic). Washington D.C.: USGS, 1956. Available from University of New Hampshire Dimond Library Documents Department & Data Center, {{cite web
column22: archivedate=2009-03-26 }} accessed 2009-03-17.</ref> Durham lies fully within the [[Piscataqua River]] (coastal) [[Drainage basin
column24: title=Water Use in New Hampshire: An Activities Guide for Teachers
column30: publisher=U.S. Department of the Interior and U.S. Geological Survey

column2: Downeaster]]'' train provides five round trips daily through [[Durham–UNH station]], with service north to [[Portland Transportation Center
column4: Freeport]], and [[Brunswick, Maine]], and south to Boston's [[North Station]].
title=Annual Estimates of the Resident Population: April 1, 2010 to July 1, 2017 (PEPANNRES): Minor Civil Divisions – New Hampshire

column1: The demographics of the town of Durham are strongly influenced by the presence of the campus of the [[University of New Hampshire]]. As of the [[census]] of 2010, there were 14,638 people, 2,960 households, and 1,544 families residing in the town. There were 3,092 housing units, of which 132, or 4.3%, were vacant. 7,266 town residents lived in group quarters such as dormitories, rather than in households. The racial makeup of the town was 93.8% [[White Americans
column2: white]], 0.9% [[African American]], 0.1% [[Native Americans of the United States
column3: Native American]], 3.2% [[Asia]]n, 0.01% [[Native Hawaiian]] or Pacific Islander, 0.4% some other race, and 1.6% from two or more races. 2.0% of the population were [[Hispanic]] or [[Hispanic and Latino Americans
column4: Latino]] of any race.<ref name=\"Census 2010 DP\">{{Cite web
column6: title=Profile of General Population and Housing Characteristics: 2010 Census Summary File 1 (DP-1): Durham town, Strafford County, New Hampshire

column1: Of the 2,960 households, 23.0% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 45.8% were headed by [[Marriage
column2: married couples]] living together, 4.4% had a female householder with no husband present, and 47.8% were non-families. 25.2% of all households were made up of individuals, and 10.2% were someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.49, and the average family size was 2.94.<ref name=\"Census 2010 DP\"/>

column1: In the town, 8.6% of the population were under the age of 18, 64.3% were from 18 to 24, 7.7% from 25 to 44, 12.5% from 45 to 64, and 6.9% were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 21.0 years. For every 100 females, there were 85.7 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 83.5 males.<ref name=\"Census 2010 DP\"/>

For the period 2011-2015, the estimated median annual income for a household was $71,190, and the median income for a family was $120,039. Male full-time workers had a median income of $72,197 versus $58,750 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the town was $22,650. 24.5% of the population and 1.4% of families were below the poverty line. 0.7% of the population under the age of 18 and 5.1% of those 65 or older were living in poverty.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Selected Economic Characteristics: 2011-2015 American Community Survey 5-Year Estimates (DP03): Durham town, Strafford County, New Hampshire
